reasoning: I’d pass on Netflix. First off, it isn’t in my circle of competence—streaming media feels more like high-tech gambling than the simple, predictable consumer businesses I understand. On durability, Netflix shows only a modest moat: operating margins are strong at 38%, but inconsistent ROE (just 6.3%) and churn in earnings growth suggest competitors can bite into its lead. Management has been aggressive with debt and dilution—issuing stock and carrying a debt-to-equity near 0.8 without paying dividends—which tells me capital allocation isn’t quite conservative. The balance sheet is stretched, owner earnings are negative, and earnings consistency is weak (0/10 periods ROE over 15%, earnings growth choppy). Valuation is absurd: our three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value (about –$24 per share conservatively), so the market is pricing in perfection, not reality. In contrast, I’d rather own durable brands like Coca-Cola or Apple (where there’s a real moat and fortress balance sheet) at fair valuations. Netflix has uncertain long-term economics, heavy content costs, and fierce competition. No margin of safety here—I’ll say no.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 6.3%; High debt to equity ratio of 0.8; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 19.6% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 41.5%) suggest some competitive advantage; High performance stability (73.8%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (4.8%, 5y), Stage 2 (2.4%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
